clinical_study.official_title: Optimising the Duration of Cooling Therapy in Mild Neonatal Encephalopathy

brief_summary.textblock: Phase II randomised control trial of whole body cooling in mild neonatal encephalopathy.

detailed_description.textblock:
BACKGROUND Approximately one million full term babies die and an equivalent number become disabled for life every year as a result of birth asphyxia related brain injury. Although cooling the body to 33.5Â°C for 72 hours benefits babies who have severe forms of brain injury, most babies have milder forms of brain injury (i.e. mild encephalopathy). It is not known whether such cooling is effective in mild encephalopathy, and if so, what the optimal duration of cooling should be. Our previous data suggest that an early measurement of the brain concentration of N-acetylaspartate (NAA, a chemical present in neurons) accurately predicts adverse developmental outcomes at two years of age, and correlates with their cognitive skills scores at this age.
AIMS
1. To identify the optimal duration of cooling therapy in mild encephalopathy that results in the highest likelihood of increased thalamic N-acetyl aspartate concentration at 1 week of age?
2. To examine if cooling therapy for this optimal duration increase thalamic N-acetyl aspartate concentration at 1 week of age, when compared with usual care (normothermia)?
METHODS A total of 220 babies with mild neonatal encephalopathy will be recruited from several large hospitals in the UK, USA and Canada, and will be randomised to usual care (normothermia) or whole body cooling for one of five durations: 24h, 36h, 48h, 60h or 72h. The thalamic concentration of N-acetylaspartate, [NAA], will be measured using 3 Tesla magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy performed between 4 and 14 days after birth.
DATA ANALYSIS AND OUTCOME MEASURES The optimal cooling duration will be first identified by estimating the duration-response curve. Briefly, thalamic [NAA] will be plotted against cooling duration and a flexible model used to describe their relationship. The optimal duration will then be selected from this duration-response curve.
The prognoses of babies allocated to the group with the optimal cooling duration will then be compared with those of normothermic controls, by assessing the difference in mean thalamic [NAA].

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
All of the following four criteria should be met:
1. Age less than six hours.
2. Evidence of acute perinatal asphyxia (metabolic acidosis (pH<7.15 and/or BE >-12) in cord and/or blood gas within 1h of birth and/or an acute obstetric event e.g. cord prolapse, abruption, shoulder dystocia)
3. Need for continued resuscitation or ventilation at 10 minutes and a 10 min Apgar score <6
4. Evidence of mild NE on an NICHD neurological examination performed between 1 and 6h of birth.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Babies without encephalopathy
2. Babies with moderate or severe encephalopathy who meet the current NICE/AAP guidelines for cooling therapy.
3. Babies with seizures (clinical and/or aEEG/EEG)
4. Babies with life threatening congenital malformations
